core_ideas.name: Utilitarianism and the Greatest Happiness Principle
core_ideas.summary: Mill's central ethical doctrine holds that actions are right in proportion as they tend to promote happiness, wrong as they tend to produce the reverse. He refines Bentham's utilitarianism by emphasizing quality as well as quantity of pleasures.
discussion_hooks: Is happiness truly the highest moral goal?
How should we weigh higher versus lower pleasures?

core_ideas.name: Liberty and Individual Autonomy
core_ideas.summary: In 'On Liberty', Mill argues that individuals should be free to act however they wish, so long as their actions do not harm others. This principle serves as a foundational argument for personal liberty and liberal democracy.
discussion_hooks: Where should society draw the line between freedom and harm?
Can freedom of expression be harmful?

core_ideas.name: The Harm Principle
core_ideas.summary: Mill articulates that the only justification for exercising power over any member of a civilized community, against their will, is to prevent harm to others. Self-regarding actions must remain free.
discussion_hooks: What counts as 'harm' in a complex society?
Does the Harm Principle justify drug laws or censorship?

core_ideas.name: Freedom of Thought and Expression
core_ideas.summary: Mill defends free speech not only as a right but as a social necessity. Even false opinions, he argues, are valuable, as their contestation strengthens the truth and guards against dogma.
discussion_hooks: Should all opinions be allowed a platform?
Can offensive speech ever be valuable to truth?

core_ideas.name: Higher and Lower Pleasures
core_ideas.summary: Mill distinguishes between pleasures of the mind and body, arguing that intellectual and moral pleasures are superior in kind to mere sensual gratification.
discussion_hooks: Are some pleasures inherently more valuable?
Can pleasure still be the standard of morality if it must be ranked?

core_ideas.name: Representative Government and Democratic Participation
core_ideas.summary: Mill believed democracy is not only a tool for governance but a vital means of moral and intellectual development for citizens. He advocated proportional representation, education, and civic responsibility.
discussion_hooks: Should all citizens have equal political power?
Does democracy cultivate virtue, or merely preference?

core_ideas.name: Women's Rights and Gender Equality
core_ideas.summary: In 'The Subjection of Women', Mill argues for the full legal and social equality of women, condemning the subordination of women as a major impediment to human progress and justice.
discussion_hooks: Can liberal principles apply equally in gender relations?
Was Mill ahead of his time or limited by it?

core_ideas.name: Education as a Means of Liberation
core_ideas.summary: Mill saw education not only as preparation for work or citizenship, but as essential to individual self-development and the cultivation of reasoned judgment.
discussion_hooks: What is the true goal of education?
Can a free society exist without public education?

core_ideas.name: Moral Sentiment and Justice
core_ideas.summary: Mill argues that the feeling of justice stems from deeply rooted social instincts—like empathy and reciprocity—refined by intellectual reflection and utility.
discussion_hooks: Is justice an instinct or a learned principle?
Can utility explain our strongest moral convictions?

core_ideas.name: Mature Individuality as a Social Good
core_ideas.summary: Mill praises individuality and self-development not merely for personal fulfillment but because diverse characters enrich society. Conformity, he warns, breeds stagnation.
discussion_hooks: How does individual eccentricity benefit the public?
Is modern society more free or more conformist?

perspectivism_framework.principle: Mill’s liberalism recognizes that no single perspective captures the whole of truth. Through open debate and personal experience, society refines its understanding of morality and knowledge.
implications: Truth emerges from the clash of differing opinions.
No institution should presume final authority over belief or lifestyle.
example_prompts: If every dissenting voice were silenced, what truths might be lost?
Should society protect unpopular opinions as a duty to future generations?

aphorisms: A person may cause evil to others not only by his actions but by his inaction.
The worth of a state in the long run is the worth of the individuals composing it.
The liberty of the individual must be thus far limited; he must not make himself a nuisance to others.
Originality is the one thing which unoriginal minds cannot feel the use of.
Genius can only breathe freely in an atmosphere of freedom.
A man who has nothing which he is willing to fight for is a miserable creature.
The only freedom which deserves the name is that of pursuing our own good in our own way.
Pleasure and freedom from pain are the only things desirable as ends.
The worth of a soul is to be measured by how much truth it can bear.
The despotism of custom is everywhere the standing hindrance to human advancement.
